thread.title: Travel Disrupted at Bangor International Airport after American Airlines midair collision in DC | News | foxbangor.com
thread.title_full: Travel Disrupted at Bangor International Airport after American Airlines midair collision in DC | News | foxbangor.com

author: Alex Schley
title: Travel Disrupted at Bangor International Airport after American Airlines midair collision in DC | News | foxbangor.com
text:
BANGOR — Travelers at Bangor International Airport were stunned Thursday by the news of an American Airlines flight’s midair collision with a military helicopter in Washington, D.C.
“We had flown out of DCA yesterday on that exact runway,” traveler Andrew Wimer said.
Despite DCA reopening Thursday at 11 a.m., all American Airlines flights to and from Bangor to Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport were canceled through Friday morning.
“We were automatically rebooked for tomorrow, but we stopped by to see what our options were,” Wimer said.
Wimer and his colleagues, who were in Maine on business, were rebooked for a 12:35 p.m. flight Friday.
“We all live in D.C. and have family down there,” Wimer said. “So we’re just going to drive to Boston and try to get a flight from there.”
As travelers scrambled to find alternate routes home, questions arose about the aircraft involved in the crash.
The plane involved in Wednesday night’s incident is the same model American Airlines uses for its Bangor-to-D.C. commuter flight. In fact, according to FlightAware, the exact plane involved in the midair collision made two trips through Bangor International Airport earlier this week—once on Sunday and again on Tuesday.
“We are constantly preparing and training for emergency scenarios because you never know. Unfortunately, accidents do happen,” the Marketing & Business Development Manager for Bangor International Airport Aimee Thibodeau said.
Despite the accident, travelers flying out of Bangor say they feel safe.
“I trust people—flying’s a lot safer than driving any day,” traveler Gerald Gibby said.
Flights between Bangor and D.C. are scheduled to resume Friday afternoon. However, airport officials remind travelers to always check their flight status before heading to the airport.
